intro: Suaeda prostrata var. iljinii, commonly known as the Iljin's saltbush, is a low-growing, mat-forming shrub native to arid and semi-arid regions of Central Asia. It is characterized by its fleshy, succulent leaves that are often covered in a waxy cuticle to reduce water loss. The plant produces small, greenish flowers that are clustered in dense inflorescences, typically blooming in late summer. It thrives in saline and alkaline soils, making it well adapted to harsh desert environments. Its botanical features reflect its evolutionary adaptations to extreme aridity and poor soil conditions.
